abstracts.cdata!:
This project was rated as generally
            satisfactory. Both World Bank and Borrower performances were
            rated as highly satisfactory. Key lessons learned included:
            Selecting but a few objectives and conditions results in
            greater impact; the Government and the Bank were able to
            focus on those measures that were critical to further the
            adjustment effort. Borrower commitment to the adjustment
            program is critical for success; ownership was built early
            on through economic and sector work, and relatively lengthy
            project preparation that included consultations with the
            private sector. A gradual approach allows for consensus
            building and sustainability of reforms. Continuity of staff
            boosts commitment and sustainability; staff who were
            familiar with reform program objectives and the
            implementation experience of previous adjustment operations
            were able to avoid pitfalls already experienced and ensure
            that implementation matched the original aims envisaged
            during program design. Close collaboration with the
            International Monetary Fund on IDA-supported operations,
            including this project, strengthened the linkages between
            macro-policies and structural reforms, and facilitated a
            greater overall impact than if programs had been implemented
            separately. Finally, the links between macroeconomic
            stability and structural reform were clearly evident
            following the privatization of majority shares in the
            two-state-owned banks which stemmed sources of monetary
            leakage and helped reduce inflation.
